title.children: Teen in custody after woman and 11-year-old girl stabbed at Ipswich home

image.altText: An artistic image showing the back of a police officer and a police car.

items.synopsis: Each year, dozens of people claim to have been injured by police, but only a handful of officers end up facing court for those alleged assaults. In South Australia, police have been accused of charging their alleged victims instead, to stop their allegations being properly investigated.

title.children: Alexander forgot his concession card on a train, a mistake which ended in his arrest and hospitalisation

image.altText: A composite image of Jim Chalmers and Philip Lowe.

items.synopsis: The trajectory of wages is just one of the unknowns in the complex situation facing the economy, and thus the government, over the next year, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: Everything's going up, including wages. But is that a good thing?

image.altText: A young girl sits in the centre of the jaws of a large shark with her sister in a wheelchair behind her

items.synopsis: The McWaters have two daughters with childhood dementia as a result of Batten Disease. They say they are luckier than some as they get to see their children grow up, but they want to see a better understanding of the disease and respite options.

title.children: Childhood dementia will cut these sisters' lives short. Their parents want better respite services â not sympathy

image.altText: AÂ stock market watcher stands in front of an ASX board.

items.synopsis: Tesla, Amazon and Apple boost US trade. Europe falls into a technical recession over the first three months of the year but another rate hike is expected.Â Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX to follow Wall St tech rally, eurozone dips into recession

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning and happy Friday! Stephanie Chalmers here to take you through the day, and it's looking set to be a pretty positive start to the session with futures pointing higher. It follows some decent gains on Wall Street, particularly for tech stocks. Amazon rose 2.5%, while Netflix ended up 2.4%. Electric carmaker Tesla also did well, rising 4.6%. The US dollar came under some pressure as oil prices slumped, and some data on weekly jobless claims was worse than expected, which helped the Aussie dollar above 67 US cents. In Europe, markets were mostly higher but eurozone economic growth was revised lower for the first quarter, down 0.1 per cent. And since that's the second quarter of economic contraction in a row, that means a 'technical recession'. It's been a pretty massive week, with the Reserve Bank raising rates for a 12th time and Australia's economic growth slowing, so stick with us, ahead of what's a long weekend in some states (the ASX will be closed on Monday).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX eyes gains after Wall Street rallies
